review.title: The RatioLog Project: Rational Extensions of Logical Reasoning
review.abstract: Higher-level cognition includes logical reasoning and the ability of question answering with common sense. Our RatioLog project addresses the problem of rational reasoning in deep question answering by methods from automated deduction and cognitive computing. In a first phase, we combine techniques from information retrieval and machine learning to find appropriate answer candidates from the huge amount of text in the German version of the free encyclopedia "Wikipedia". In a second phase, an automated theorem prover tries to verify the answer candidates on the basis of their logical representations. In a third phase - because the knowledge may be incomplete and inconsistent -, we consider extensions of logical reasoning to improve the results. In this context, we work toward application of techniques from human reasoning: We employ defeasible reasoning to compare the answers w.r.t. specificity, deontic logic, normative reasoning, and model construction. Moreover, we use integrated case-based reasoning and machine learning techniques on the basis of the semantic structure of the questions and answer candidates to learn giving the right answers.

sections.heading: 3 Conclusions
sections.text: The deep answering of questions requires not only pattern and indexing techniques, but also rational thinking. This has been investigated within the framework of the RatioLog project, as shown in this article. Techniques of machine learning with similarity measures and case-based thinking, defeatist thinking with (a revision) of the specification criterion, and normative thinking with deontic logic help in the selection of good candidates for answers. If, however, background knowledge encodes mainly linguistic knowledge - without general healthy world knowledge - then the effect on finding good candidates for answers is low. Therefore, future work will focus on using even more background knowledge (e.g. from ontology databases) so that rational thinking can be used more effectively when applied to this concrete knowledge.
